person.persName: John Baylis Earle (Hopkins County attorney and coal baron)

body.p: A Kentucky attorney. Educated in a Hopkins County neighborhood school, otherwise self-educated. Taught school for a short time in 1843. Married to Sarah C. Woolfolk Earle. Father of Lucien Earle, Luella Earle, Kittie Earle, Portia Earle, and Augusta Earle. Owned four enslaved persons in 1860. Member of the Whig Party and Republican Party. Served as Assessor of Muhlenburg County, Kentucky. Worked in the flat boat trade. Studied law in Hopkins County under the direction of John Cook. Admitted to the bar and commenced practice in Madisonville, Kentucky. A partner in the law firm of Earle & Waddill, with Otway Waddill, at Madisonville, Kentucky in 1852. A sole practitioner in Madisonville, Kentucky in 1853, 1854, 1856, and 1859. Elected county attorney for Hopkins County in 1855 through 1859. Continued private practice as an attorney. Founder of Southeast Kentucky Petroleum, Coal, Mining, and Transportation Company, with H. M. Van Arman and Thomas E. Young, in 1865.
